race.name: SBT GRVL
race.tagline: Champagne gravel at altitude - where the pros come to play and the views will make you forget about the suffering

distances.description: Elite race course with rolling enclosure - the flagship event

race.terrain: Famous 'champagne gravel' - smooth, high-quality gravel roads through working ranches, aspen groves, and sage-studded hills at high altitude
race.weather: High-altitude Colorado summer - cool mornings (40s-50s°F), warm afternoons (70s-80s°F), potential afternoon thunderstorms. Unpredictable mountain weather.

length.explanation: Black course at 108 miles puts this firmly in the 100-150 mile category. Substantial distance that demands fitness and strategy, though not ultra-distance territory.

technicality.explanation: The famous 'champagne gravel' is actually quite smooth and fast, with mixed terrain including some rougher sections and descents. Technical enough to keep you honest, but not extreme singletrack territory.

elevation.explanation: 8,189 feet of climbing on the Black course is serious vertical. Multiple significant climbs including Dunkley Pass demand climbing legs and smart pacing throughout the day.

climate.explanation: Late June in the Colorado Rockies means variable conditions - cool mornings, warm afternoons, and the ever-present threat of afternoon thunderstorms. Not extreme, but requires preparation.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 6,700 feet and climbing to ~8,500 feet puts this firmly in high-altitude territory. Riders from sea level will feel the thin air significantly - acclimatization is strongly recommended.

logistics.explanation: Yampa Valley Regional Airport offers direct flights from 12 cities, and Denver is a 3-hour drive. Steamboat has good lodging options, but it's still a destination requiring planning and the event sells out via lottery.

adventure.explanation: This is bucket-list territory. World-renowned champagne gravel through stunning Colorado ranch country, aspen groves, and mountain vistas. The scenery alone makes this a must-do pilgrimage for serious gravel riders.

prestige.explanation: One of the crown jewels of gravel cycling. Independent event founded by Amy Charity in 2019, attracts world-class pros (Keegan Swenson's three-peat, Lauren De Crescenzo, Lauren Stephens) despite not being part of any major series. Iconic status on its own merit.

race_quality.explanation: Elite-level organization with professional race production, rolling enclosure for the Black course, 5 well-stocked aid stations, separate elite starts, and a multi-day expo experience. World-class in every detail.

experience.explanation: Life-changing territory. From packet pickup on Yampa Street to the champagne gravel roads through working ranches, the Zipp Cow Creek finish, and the post-race celebration in one of Colorado's best mountain towns - this is what gravel dreams are made of.

community.explanation: Founded with equal prize money from day one, strong emphasis on respect for local ranching community, inclusive with para-cycling resources and e-bike options. The vibe is welcoming and the gravel tribe comes out in force - 2,750 riders strong.

field_depth.explanation: Despite not being an LTGP event, the prestige attracts world-class pros. Keegan Swenson, Lauren Stephens, Lauren De Crescenzo, and top gravel racers compete here. Strong prize purse and iconic status draw elite fields.

value.explanation: At $275 for most courses, it's premium pricing for a premium event. You get Life Time-level production value, excellent aid stations, and a world-class experience, but it's definitely not budget-friendly.

expenses.explanation: Total trip costs add up quickly - flights to remote Yampa Valley or 3-hour drive from Denver, lodging in a ski resort town during summer, and the registration fees. Expect $1,000-1,500+ for the full experience from most locations.

uniqueCharacteristics: World-famous 'champagne gravel' - the smoothest, fastest gravel roads on Earth
Independent event attracting world's best gravel racers through prestige alone
Founded by Amy Charity with equal prize purses since 2019
Routes through working Colorado ranches and stunning mountain scenery
Four course options from 25-108 miles for all abilities
Steamboat Springs ranked #3 Best Small Towns in USA
Estimated $4.5 million economic impact - one of the world's largest gravel events
race.popularity: Very High - one of the most prestigious gravel events in the world
